'Worst Rainfall in 30 Years': Thailand Flooding Hits 700,000 People, Leaves 21 Dead By Eric Chaney Published Jan 9 2017 10:35 AM EST weather.com Widespread flooding in Thailand's south has killed 21 people. Unseasonably heavy rain has hit 12 out of 67 provinces. Around 700,000 people have been affected. 
Widespread flooding in Thailand's south has killed 21 people, affected hundreds of thousands more, and hit the nation’s rubber industry hard. 
“Severe flooding is because of the worst rainfall in more than 30 years ", Prime Minister Prayut Chan-O-Cha told RTE. 
Thailand has deployed military assets to combat the effects of the flooding, which has affected around 700,000 people, MENAFN reports. The floods have cut off roads and rail tracks, forced the closure of airports, collapsed bridges, and left thousands stranded in their homes. In some villages, the water level has reached roof height. 
(MORE: Deep Freeze Gripping Europe Blamed for More Than a Dozen Deaths ) 
“A major effort is required to ensure people are moved to higher ground and receive food and medical supplies,” junta spokesman Gen. Sansern Kaewkamnerd told MENAFN. 
Southern Thailand is a major rubber-producing area, and the flooding comes at a particularly bad time for farmers. 
"I've had orders from China but we aren't even sure if we can meet these orders because of the havoc the floods have caused," Uthai Sonlucksub, president of the Natural Rubber Council of Thailand told Reuters."This the worst impact we have had in the area in 10 years." 
Uthai said that rubber prices would increase this year because demand is set to exceed supply. 
(MORE: Storm Topples Iconic Sequoia in Northern California ) 
“Floods mainly cause damage to roads, bridges and transport routes, but not much to machinery or the production process, which are generally covered by insurance,” he said. “So the impact on the private sector is quite limited.” 
Namchaisiri told the Post that the Joint Standing Committee on Commerce, Industry and Banking have estimated damages to the economy will be around $280 million and should not exceed $420 million. The Weather Company An IBM Business
